Elisabeth Gray a repository of personal and academic work

Curriculum Vitae

Technology is the underlying theme of my career, but my fascination with societal conflict is at the heart of everything I do. It fuels my ongoing process of learning, unlearning, and relearning and has made me a more capable academician and professional.

I’ve gleaned essential skills and broadened my perspective in unimagined ways while working in retail, non-profit, technical, education, and financial industry positions. These roles have been as much a part of my development as a socio-political technologist as the courses I've taken through educational institutions. I utilize them regularly as I continue to work toward a greater understanding of the relationships between technology and society as they pertain to conflict.

Education

  • Arizona State University; 2013-2015
    • Master of Science in Global Technology and Development expected May 2015
  • Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis; 2000-2005
    • Bachelor of Science in Media Arts and Sciences; concentration in Journalism
    • Minor in French
    • Computer Science certificate coursework

Research Interests

  • The relationship(s) between technology and society, especially with regard to conflict
  • The role of media in the genocides in Bosnia and in Rwanda
  • The role of social media in conflict
  • Middle Eastern conflict
  • Palestinian-Israeli conflict

Papers

  • What is Development?
  • Technology and Development
  • Technology and Societal Change
  • Why Are Some Nations "Rich" and Others "Poor"?
  • The United States' Approach to Conflict and Development
  • Never Again? The US Response to Genocide in Bosnia and Rwanda
  • Building Fences: Saudi Arabia's Strategy for National Security
  • Information Warfare: The Roles of Social Media in Conflict
  • Israel-Palestine Conflict
  • An Assessment of Mexico's Technology Policy
  • Se Va a Poner Feo: The Culture of Violence in Mexico and Its Impact on Development Efforts

Presentations

  • Out of Sight, 2005
    • Presented undergraduate capstone—a video documentary on homeless youth in Indianapolis, Indiana—to a lecture hall of instructors and peers
    • Facilitated a question-and-answer session for instructors and peers on the research, production, and findings of the project
    • Defended research, production, and findings before a faculty panel

Work Experience

Braintree

I started as an Integration Support Specialist, helping customers integrate their sites with the Braintree payment gateway. In 2013, I collaborated with a lead developer to migrate all of the company's internal documentation into a single domain using Atlassian Confluence. I now lead a dedicated team of content managers in the creation and maintenance of internal product, process, and procedural content in Confluence as well as public-facing support articles in Github.

  • Knowledge Management Lead; Chicago, IL; 2014-Present
  • Ops Support Specialist; Chicago, IL; 2013-2014
  • Integration Support Specialist; Chicago, IL; 2011-2013

University of Chicago Charter School

My initial role of Technology Support Specialist evolved into that of Technology Director on the grade 6-12 Woodlawn campus. I succeeded in reducing the technology loss rate on campus from 36% to 3.69% by the end of my first year and to 0.71% at the end of my third. I was responsible for the deployment of over 600 Apple computers in a 1:1 program for students, development of policy and procedure, reconciliation of the technology budget, management of technology-related assets, development of training sessions for teachers and students, and technical support for computer-based assessments such as the NWEA MAP tests.

  • Technology Director; Chicago, IL; 2009-2011
  • Tech Support Specialist; Chicago, IL; 2008-2009

Apple Inc.

The culmination of responsibilities earned at Apple over four years included training new employees, teaching customers about computer hardware and software and troubleshooting, diagnosing and repairing hardware and software issues while maintaining clear and direct communications with coworkers and customers in order to achieve company and consumer expectations.

  • Mac Genius; Chicago, IL; 2006-2008
  • Mac Visual Specialist; Indianapolis, IN; 2004-2006

Gold Wing Touring Association

I started as an intern while in college at Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis and was promoted to a full-time role within five months. I was responsible for designing, organizing, and editing the non-profit association’s monthly magazine, negotiating and communicating with advertisers and printers and developing marketing, advertising plans and media for the association.

  • Media and Marketing Manager; Indianapolis, IN; 2003-2004

Conferences Attended

  • Illinois Computing Educators, 2009-2010
  • PowerSchool University, 2010

Memberships

  • Technology Educator, Illinois Computing Educators; Chicago, IL; 2009-2011
